comments: First real attempt after seasoning. Several small adjustments at FC did not react as quickly as expected.  Probably should have finished hotter or longer/ 408 finishing temp.  Confusion around BT readings due to lack of clarity and mixed nomenclature from Allio.

Better results to drop temp by increasing fan speed near FC. Some unnecessary fiddling with P's.  Tried lower D speed as Roasting Navigated said D8 is ideally less than threshold for centrufigle force lock. Accidently hit cool at first alarm but didn't drop... lowered fan and increased the auto-d1 drum speed to keep it cracking longer

First BBP PH try. PH to 260 9 mins + 2 min hold and droped to 240 & 245 over about 8 additional mins. 
Tried P8 w/ larger batch size. Difficult to control FC rise. Increase of Fan B4 first crack might have brought temp up. Color appeared darker as roaster becomes more seasoned and chaffe looked burnt (higher PH?). Beans have nice mild milk chocolate smell in early degassing.

Tried to use an increased fan speed to mitgate the rise at the first crack.
used about a 20-25 min preheat, did not see a huge positive effect from that PH.  Should step up to P8 at charge to get a greater ROR start

Started with a long 35mins PH to 260, then droppd to 240.  Began at P9 to try and get a >20 ROR spike. Planned to drop 1P every 2:30, but needed more at the end.  Again tended to plateau ROR in middle of roast.
Dissapointed in the shape but understanding how modulation or vatious methods can and cannot be represented in the profile.
Tried to pick at yellowing point. Potentially IR @150

roastName: #7 Ethopian - no fan, applied reading, meh
comments:
Could not control ROR at 1C, again at 10. Hoping it could get it down to 5.
I tried to follow several steps in Rao's book including dropping power 2 min B4 1c (followed by fan increase 5 sec later), drop power 45 sec B4 1C, and halve during 1C (althought i started halving at 7% DTR instead of 12%).  A few panicy points as well when I notcied the curves looking mostly like my previous ones and not dropping.  Bullet on dedicated extension cord, fan across the room. Roasted 5pm and hottter outside

First guat roast, Felt like I did a good job of droping power to keep ROR falling. Based on some of my written notes but wanted to drop power after the inital ROR peak to keep it falling.  Potentially negative due to sorta crash at end, dropped below and 0 ROR and dropped at or below 200C. Overall, getting better...instinct or luck
dropped heat a lot to control high ROR,  found a very low and slow approach to FC. nice smell, confusing but good
Rob coming thru with the details on lower charge and power to get smoother ROR. Potential flat line in there

roastName: #11 Ethiopia Agaro Nano Challa w/ Rob

comments:
slower roast, attempted to follow previous Peru. Found FC spike before sound at 196 degs, should plan to drop P 1 min sooner at 190ish? 
Seemingly went longer as I wanted to get rid of rasin mottel...

attempted to plan to drop P before 1C since PNG was plateaued.  Did this a little better and found the 400g roast was behaving a fair bit different than 450, 13% different weight. Major crash at end that couldn't be countered with heat:  eh - bland taste of chewing beans

This is another weird experiment.  First tried and the roast temp peaked at ~10ROR and plummeted... did not yellow after 8-9 mins..I think the Power was malfunctioning. call it a super long soak.  Then I cooled and pre-heated again to 230 and roasted on mostly 9 with increasing the fan speed.  Seemingly good results wtih 1C ~8 ROR. Used a dip in Power here and bought it back up to avoid a crash. Finished at 204 (although wish I was higher and 5 deg ROR at 18% DEV.  Nice taste after roasting, slightly tingy metalic smell?

roastName: #18 Eithopian DP Shakios Korommii with sm new DP mix
comments: The roast temp was higher than expected mid roast but I feel it was well modulated with significant and pre-emptive increases in fan speed as well as a temp dip at 1C
Good roast with short to no soak.  had ~80g of washed eithopian in there which may have been early 1C aspect(?)
Fan was rubbing in the back causing a late spike in heat and problematic

Says 230 PH but maybe only 200, slow Turning Point and quick drop on P7, probably several things on the low end of what is needed. I tried to bring this below my typical but this felt too long.  Marcelle's HBD batch

220 charge was higher than previous turning point. steady decline resulted in a bit of necessary lateral movement to get thru 1C without dropping hard and stalling at end, actually did a little end shuffle where I didn't drop but turned it to cool and back to on at the end for another 20-30 sec.
Typical, sorta poorly controlled and ending mottled and past 'very light'   could not get a strong ROR ending finish without crashing
Well (self) managed declining ROR with minimal input except for around 1C and TD. Next time go a little longer
Just a hair darker with some on-the-fly adjustments to keep this medium roast going 25 seconds longer than the previous. Taste will tell
Felt like low charge temp maybe have resulted in slower 2nd D (slower ROR drop) uncertain.
Felt like low charge temp maybe have resulted in slower 2nd D (slower ROR drop) uncertain.
Tried a combo of heat and fan with a 225 PH, but didn't get stability to avoid the crash

roastName: #31 Ethiopia Lima Musu washed and crashed
comments: Really fast due to high temps after intital ROR drop.

Cupping: Much flatter and more empty than expected. Not much sweetness or rich/chocolate typical Guat flavor. 
Roast: Curve looked like a good roast given first at low temps (30 F in Pittsburgh adding a few to the garage, maybe 8), my water isn't frozen
waited a bit longer than a previous guat to drop temp because ambient escape.  245 PH
Damn cold, 2nd roast. Tried to play it off #32 but had more of a crash that I would have liked and it hung at 200-201 for too long

34 outside.  Crash at end is when I opened the garage door and kicked on the 2 fans in the garage! Also used green pad atop bullet to reduce heat loss in low temps.   YP at 165 was fine with visual change. Increased fan here. Tried power dip b4 1C.... Interesting -> 1C seemed to come early on this soaked roast.

roastName: #35 Kenya no soak - FC stall, balls
comments:
Smaller batch size with mid-sized PH... still have post 1C problems that could be causing baked flavors. Attempted to resist turning up the fan with very cold air entering the system. 
Cooled on box fan

cold AF out,  garage is quite cold.  Tried to go quick and hot early, extend the mailard (althought that wasn't perfect, and keep it going thru FC... Seemed to work with hesitation to run fan at end (very cold air entering the machine).  First chew of post roast bean is a bit ashey..

Its a bit unnerving coming into the yellowing and browing with high RORs.  An articicle recomended trying to burn thru the drying phase hot to preserve some acidity, but then extend the mailard to get fruit and sweetness... however when set up with a hot drying phase, its hard to slow down the momentum, yet not stall momentum at the end

roastName: #38 Ethiopain Yirg.   LATE and HOT (205?) FC - PH 215,
comments: Garage open at 4min.  Holding steady, looked like a lot of chaff from this Yirg so I upped fan a tried to hold heat thru FC.  Very supprised that audible FC wasn't until 205C..   First notes of taste are ashy with some fruit...althought nice outside bean character, smooth finish
Less Ashy, nice taste at end

roastName: #40 Ethiopian Yirg 235PH - Fast roast 209 drop but light!
comments: 209 drop but visibly lighter, picked out 2 grams (roast weight corrected) of light and grassy beans

adjustemnts at 170ish to attempt drop ROR instead of plateauinng around FC... Test was supposed to let roast expand in DEV time but it reached 209 at a very similar time....   Result: Low acid, medium body, med-high flavors of a fruity cup

pretty well behaved roast after quite closely following the last few.  Seems like a higher PH with a higher temp in the garage.   Would like to see if the low ROR at the end and a drop temp ~2 degs less than the previous roasts changes flavor

Attempted temp based power % based on Rao's CRBP.. did not appropriately account for fan changes on a cold night (30F outside) .  Beans quite hard with only 11.6% WL althought i was aftraight they were going a little long
Cupping:  High acid, moderate flavor

roastName: #45 Kenya  with little to no fan. still crashed 40s after FC
comments: pushed this roast a little further but it still crashed 40 sec after 1C.  the cold weather can't be helping but it does tend tto suck heat hard!
kinda ugly beans,   looks like kenyan FC crash,  so cold outside

Pretty wonky chart. temp increases in unexpeted places when I was reducing heat.. ibtsTemps flatlineed after FC althought the ROR was still 5-2... potentially related to the method of smoothing in ROR?
Higher PH after quite a long warm up. Roared right into this roast in cold temps, no prob. about a 40sec dip at 180C seemed to control some of the FC spike with limited crash (but thats bean temp)
Large dip/spike after ROR peak due to pulling back cover off for fan rubbing. cancled playback at end to adjust power and time at FC. Interesting samem weight loss with a longer DTR
First recipie built off #48.   I missed the first P7-P6 step in the roast and needed to do a manual adjust for P drop on DTR at the end of the roast. However pretty happy
not well executed roast!

Bit of a struggle with this higher batch size.  Started wiht lower momentum than expected and gave it a bit more power, it took off on me at the end and had a hard time bringing it down. Over all, much longer of a roast than i'd like.
decent roast, challenges in manageing 700g
Pretty good roast following the last 700g. seems like 600 was more manageable to control

Pretty well controlled roast that I put more energy into the middle of.  Temps caught up to #55 but a little extra fan slowed the ROR near the end. Will be interesting to see if a little longer development but lower peak temp changes flabor notably.
friday night cold snap in pittsburgh. new small 5lb batch is has some real crisp popcorn smells at 6:30 in the roast.

roastName: #59 Ethiopia Halo Bariti - 600 good PH faster
comments: a bit faster than the last roasts with no soak and higher heat.  went into FC with a significatnly higher ROR

roastName: #60 Ethiopia Halo Bariti - 600 slower malliard and DTR
comments: used a little more fan on this one, but i'll never know i mixed it with the last
Kenya & Burrundi, maybe more. Hot and fast dry.   (OLD beans maybe low moisture). but worked hard to drop their temp regualrly seemed to be fine.
2nd  in houston
220 PH and tried to slow it down. Dip to P2 was too low ahead of PH.

Exhaust fan is gap between M-H.   Stalled out and didn't really get into much of a FC. Slow cooling process as well, Lots of quakers.  I don't have high expectations
- Cupping Notes:  pretty damn good berry flavor and sweetness. Great coffee where I would say this sideways development was 'pre-bake' didn't result in baked flavors.  A bit of power at the end to push into FC and a drop at a low final BT retained the light roast notes with great development.  Not grassy or awkward. Still a little bit of nice acid and tea-like flavor.
stalled near FC again. Next time: Use P8-9 longer at start to get that momentum up.  Note: lower loss%
Dropped at 199 with a pretty good FC but it was out of ROR momentum.  If I didn't reduce the power so much I could have gone further as I wanted to take this more to a medium roast.

Trying to got harder on this one and avoid dropping the ROR to zero at 201C.. Attempting 208 drop.
Result: Started very hot, maybe extending 9 was too much. Panicked a bit and crashed it. Unable to get over 205.  Beans and an immediate shot tasted pretty sharp (metal acrid at behind my front teeth). No choc or body

roastName: #71 El Sav - DP Don Ricardo - 235 PH
comments:
Working off #66 ETH I'm gonna try to start hot and get to 205 drop.    
Results:  seems to work well enough, P9 started a bit too high and had to have a lot of faith bringing it down. 
NOTES: interestingly the chaff on this bean seems to have blackened and stuck ON the bean about 10-20% of the time
First roast after the cleaning of the inside faceplate and fan +.  Really well controlled for what I wanted to do.  Early bean tasting of fruit and chocolate. Happy with that.

change yp. first kilo batch.  High PH worked well, actually a lot hotter than expected.
Pretty damn good results. Not mega fruity but mild round and pleasant
5C PH less than the DP El Salv.  Behaved quite similar with a little crash at the end. May not be quite the same of a fruity bean, but has potential.
CRASHED hard, whoops.  also fast to start. maybe need to start hotter and not give it as much power?

roastName: #77   Guate Jilotepeque SM 700g 255PH, lots of fan
comments: Testing 255 vs last 240PH. Tried to slow down the early roast speed and use more FAN to keep the temps down. will be interesting to see results in cupping
Pretty good roast with minor stall.  Really see how that initial momentum just does it's thing and early power changes are hard to decipher

Too fast again. then stalled at FC. ugh
bad roast IMO
Decent roast, probably started with a higher PH than needed (it's nearly 80 degrees in the roasting room). Thus 215 could have kept the start slower.

roastName: #81 Guatemala SM Jil - PH215 mostly fan - 214 drop
comments: Tried something different, went back to a lower batch size and used lower PH and power to limit the initial spike and crash. It worked.  Just one power change and then fan. Humid afternoon. Good roast to  great roast.  59g/100ml. Very smooth, sweet, and chocolately espresso on 01/21/22 - 12 days after roast

roastName: #82 - Guatemala SM Jil  215PH same as last
comments: Good roast again. dropped at 413 and maybe lost a few less in the cooling? slightly diff loss weight.  61.6g/100ml

roastName: #83 - Ethiopia 210PH low power method as last 2
comments:
Nice roast, a little faster than @bradm 's July 20, 2020 Excellent roast! .   Good roast  61.6g/100ml.
espresso never turned out to be great

Lower TP and rise  than #81 probably due to 100g more greens and Ambient Temp. First roast of the day but 1 hr preheat. no soak and waited longer to raise fan to work on catching up. (greens at 110g/100ml) roaster 63.8g/100ml
Roasted 63.4g/100ml

roastName: #86 Ethiopia DP Super Soaker long fan whoops 210drop
comments: weird one. i put it to F8 instead of P8.... we'll see how this goes. 56.8g/100ml

roastName: #87 El Salvador - 300g 1st, a bit too fast
comments: First go on this bean and 300g to match the sourdough beans. Seemed to go in a bit hot and fast to 1st so i purposely stalled it a bit to develop more and dropped at 215.  Beans have some strong notes of grape outta the cooling basket.   72g/100 ml green - 40 g/100ml roasted

roastName: #88 El Salvador - slow low power, stalledish, 300g - 215 drop
comments: idk this one wasn't great. P5 with this low pre-heat and the ROR didn't get to 15 on the initial ramp. 72g/100ml green. - 46.6g/100ml roasted

300 g of El Salv + 165g of whole wheat sourdough starter + 185g of water + pinch of sugar, 2.5 days ferment and then washed. Ended as 525g wet. baked at 120-150d for about 35 mins, and that wasn't working great so I put them in 3 mesh sieves and a fan for 3 days. They dried to about 390g. PH at 240 and P9, sucked lots of power. Early smoke was sweet, a bit like hickory wood. Yellowing and browning was highly variable. 25-30% of beans were barely yellow while some were a dark translucent brown, clearly not evenly progressing. At ~180C puffy-pops in early FC, sounded like popcorn but you could see the beans were still light brown variable colors and texture.  Roaring FC about 10 deg below 200, kept it going and at 210, some beans out of the trier were still soft and pliable. Ended up going pretty hot to 220 just to try to dry things up. Tasting the beans are pretty wild and sweet blackberry or grape candy-like, but also very dark and smokey flavors due to the high drop temp

OH LORD - realized my scale has been in gn nor grams!   At least or probably since I've been in Houston.  Lots of previous problems starting to make sense but I will not be able to clean up all my errors.  Tried to use low PH 500g profile with only 5deg higher profile and it's not working great.  The numbers below are correct in grams, not sure what i was doing before

Roast was looking very uneven at 190 and past 200, had to go a fair bit higher and dropped at 216, probably some of it is too dark.
Seems like a lot of quakers too
Last of this bean, managed to keep the ROR high on this 700g batch through most of the roast.  Surface is still a bit uneven and wrinkeled, maybe I could have extended to to 214+

Pretty uneven roast. More quakers than I've ever seen, tons of chaff in the window (and trier) made it hard to keep up with progress.  Dropped at 212 with some dark beans but still many light ones, not high expectations

Roast was looking very uneven at 190 and past 200, had to go a fair bit higher and dropped at 216, probably some of it is too dark.
Seems like a lot of quakers too
Great roast on Drip!   mild chocolate and moderate berry and candy.    YES
randomly dropped to P0 at 185 when I stepped away, don't know

roastName: #99 -  Ethiopia	Dry Process Hambela Dabaye - another 0 drop
#100 Columbia Hulia double ferment - heater error do not use
#101 El Salvador Siberia Washed w/ Keith
#102 Columbia Huila Double Ferment -  hot night
#105 Ethiopia yirg worka natural from rob 5lb
comments: tried to slow down the maillard a bit but got the over heating due to the back room being 35 degrees
well done

roastName: #107 Ethiopia Yirg Worka Natty - Good bridge between last two
comments: Really happy with the control and steps of this roast.  Came out great from the learnings of the previous two. Dropped about 15 secs after intense berry notes
Decent roast, this will be compared to the Ethiopian to dropped at the same temp

roastName: #109 Colombia - Huila Double Ferment - 2min soak - 219 drop. whoops then dark
comments: Well this one I goofed up by setting F9 rather than P9 for over 2 mins, for a very long soak and likely loss of momentum
These Columbia roast/green ratios for Columbia double ferments are high. I might need to roast them 'longer'. Longer yellowing time or maybe further past FC
messed this one up by entering in the weight and data from 113,  i don't think I can re find this data

roastName: #113 Ethiopia Mix Refisia and Hambela Dabaye
comments: Good roast to show effect of longer soak and slow yellowing
old Sulawesi Toraja Pulul pulu beans have probably been sitting around for a year-ish
Roast was going fine, until I started screwing with it. I thought it was too hot and I stalled it out a bit.  Had nice chocolate notes at 1C and still hope for the best.

roastName: #119 Crown Jewel Ethiopia Organic Wenago Wolde Hirbe Raised Bed Natural
comments:
Whoops, I loaded the wrong recipe and only figured it out when I saw the different behavior and divergence after the peak ROR.  Changed a lot to try to get it to calm down but probably a bit too fast.  This had an even more uneven color than the next one (120).  Also I'm unsure if roast world has a bug where it jumps roasts and I enter the the wrong info in the wrong roast... This was a pain in the butt again.
This light and fast roast was preferred over the slower one

roastName: #120 Crown Jewel Ethiopia Organic Wenago Wolde Hirbe Raised Bed Natural
comments: Good roast here. I followed the notes on the Crown Jewel site and really had to drop temp at 180C to keep it from taking off. I probably slowed it a bit too much and extended it more than needed.  Next time try D7 with 500 and let it finish a bit faster.

no soak I backed off power early to try and avoid the FC spike, however it seemed to have lost momentum.
Early tastes of this bean were poor.  Way too limey and dull.  No berry or sweetness. poor espresso

Followed the previous roast quite closely with a sharp crash after first crack. Maybe consult Rao's BP book for more insight to stop crash. Continued to have issue with editing comments on the wrong roast
Good little roast, started with a lower PH than I wanted but held it to P9 a while to keep it going. would probably repeat
Decent roast that slowed hard because of a no change error.  Trying to figure out whats happening with the post 1C crashes

Decent roast with hot peak (flick) in middle that rushed into first crack. Bean crashed a bit.  Got to 209 quicker. Look out for body in the development.   Cupping: Berry and candied fruit aroma, a little paper and cardboard through the middle.  Cooled with more sweetness and cinnamon.  Preferred to 126

Smoothed out the curve with a quicker move to P8 and F3. Later first crack then #125 with the same total time and temp. Expected longer Maillard phase, expected more flavor and body.  Cupping:  Less sweetness and flavor, a little more mellow and rounded. Hard to differentiate, but less preferred than #125

roastName: #127 - Colombia Santa Barbra Natural - 1st & on air only
comments: controlled this pretty well with only fan adjustments

roastName: #128 - Colombia Santa Barbra Natural - Power only, F3 if poss
comments: Trying this as an experiment against the fan only mode.   I lost some momentum after the peak ROR but got it back and finished with a good and quick ROR. satisfied and excited to taste the difference between this and 127

roastName: #129 Colombia Santa Barbra Natural Mostly fan 245
comments: Pretty decent roast. at 700g I only went 5 degree C higher than a 600 gram roast and it showed.  This lagged behind and took longer to heat up and keep going.  tried to finish it hard to make up for a slower start. Look for that in the taste and report back.
Went in hot and coasted or controlled it pretty well.  Took this one faster and lighter than others, especially at the finish without too much of a flick or crash. hopeful.

roastName: #131  Ethiopia Crown Jewel Wenago Wolde Hirbe Natural
comments: Started with an unplanned soak.
from happymug.com, we tried to take it to second crack and roasted in F.   limited body but decent
Again in F degrees, dropped at 420 which seems high. Rob says it could have gone darker.

Good roast. not much to say here
Other technical notes about JSON data
First roast with  SoftwareVersion "FE:v1.113.0;BE:v1.40.12;Comms:v1.10.56",
missing :
Firmware ID
and zero values for:
"beanChargeTemperature": 0,
  "beanDropTemperature": 0,
  "drumChargeTemperature": 0,
  "drumDropTemperature": 0,

I used the same beans, batch size, and preheat as 136 but used a 1 min soak on this one, with the same TP and other results through the middle of the roast.  Possibly notably, this later roast have a very long and steady preheat, showing how the thermal mass helped steady it. But also demonstrating how hard it is to correlate effects

roastName: #138 - Ethiopia Wenagno Wolde Hirbe Natural - Andrew Coe recipe test, too hot
comments:
Using Andrew Coe's world championship recipe.  250 pre heat, F5.  Noted Higher peak ROR.
Basically the whole thing was running very hot.  I dropped a lot of power and increased the fan but proabably did a bit too much out of frustration.   Very fast roast then I crashed it and potentially baked roast with a flat dev ROR

roastName: #139 - Ethiopia Wenagno Wolde Hirbe Natural - adjusted WC for larger batch and slower
comments: High peak ROR, and lower TP, I thought this was going to adjust just right but it dropped pretty quick and made the ROR after 1C a bit hard to work with. The cut from P5 to P4 at first crack was not good. should have

I'm roasting a rwanda mushyoni batch of 700g  with a 19.1C ambient temp. I'd like to produce nice fruit and wine notes that the green bean distributor suggested. I'd like quite a light roast. I think I prefer trying to start with a 250 preheat temp, can you suggest a newer profile to finish at about 205C in ~9 mins . Can you suggest a recipe for me? 
Certainly! Starting with a higher preheat temperature of 250°C can help you achieve a quicker heat-up phase, which is beneficial for a light roast profile. For a 700g batch of Rwanda Mushyoni beans, aiming for a finish temperature of around 205°C in approximately 9 minutes, here's a suggested roast profile:

Results: BAKED!  Way under powered. AI..... no good

Following the AI roast, I needed to recenter my profile. I tried something similar to what Marcel sent me in a text last night for his african blend. This went a fair bit faster and hotter for me and I ended up crash/stalling it as i tried to slow it down at the end.
Decently controlled roast on a nice spring day. Bean taste didn't give a big fruit flavor but we will see
Good rolling crack

roastName: #144 - Guatemala - Coffee Kids - goofy preheat/start timing
comments: thought it was preheating but it was off, so when I dropped the green, nothing happened and the heat was probably 240ish. Then I also forgot to remove the funnel and cap the inlet, so it had quite a rocky start with low rise and temps

#blend of some older Ethiopian and Rwanda beans.  Blew it with a hot hot pre-heat so I went @espressofun mode and oscillated the power and fan to get a slightly better time.  Possibly only with such a small roast that didn't need the heat momentum
